In a world of darkness, comes kreeping the vampires of Thingiverse.
And let me see your best pictures!!

-Download the STL file.
-Print "vampsfangs3" with your own support, ideally raftless. I did mine in ABS, layer thickness of 0.25. Full infill.
-Or print "vampswithsupport"
-Remove the support carefully.
-Clean up with sand paper, make sure all sharp things are smoothed, otherwise in a few minutes your mouth will be full with blestures.
-Rinse under water.
-Dry in a clothe.
WARNING:
The next steps are definitly not advised to do. If you do so,it is at your own risk. Acetone is a poison.
-Dunk only the teeth in Acetone for a few minutes so they become shiny and smooth.
-You can add some tea in the Acetone for to color the teeth.
-Suit the color to your needs.
-Let the fangs dry over day to make sure the Acetone evaporates.
-Rinse well again.
-When comes the night pick up your fangs and wear them.
-Use your tong up and down for to make them GROWWWW!!!!

description.text:

The only files changed here are in the "engine" file. The "hull" is exactly the same as in the original project, it's only listed here for completeness.

ABS is recommended, since this (and the original) design require a bit of flex to the hull in order to snap in the engine.

author: knetic

description.text:
I found some paraboloids on thingiverse, but none that were written in a short way. Though this scad script is only 26 lines long, it makes a smooth paraboloid, but the rendering time is long. That's openscad's fault!

It's just a loop of scad cylinders. scad cylinders can be chopped off cones , which is what we're using here. The radius is proportional to the square root of the height. People should learn how to integrate this way in calc 2.

The main disadvantage of this is that scad is creating the end faces on the chopped cones (the primitive cylinder element), and we only really want the visible faces. This is why it renders slowly. The computer is still having to 'think' about many surfaces that are not visible in the end.

title: E3D Titan Extruder Fan Mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a quick remix of the E3D Titan fan holder by Gyrobot (original design). I loved the rear mount design that allowed easy access to the nozzle. However by having the fan rear mounted I was limited to printing objects at 160mm tall to avoid having the fan holder hit the frame. (I have a RepRap Prusa i3)

I decided to front mount the fan holder using two mounting points of the E3D Titan extruder using two M3x35mm screws and washers. The radial fan is held with m3x20mm screws with nuts and washers. This allows the x-carriage to reach the full 200mm height for those tall prints.

A dual radial fan set up could work if used in conjunction with the original rear mount holder.

Downsides: Makes removing/changing filament slightly more awkward. The idler force indicator is covered by the mount - fixable.

Printed in black PLA with supports touching the build plate. Sliced with Cura.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Support touching the build plate is a must.
Black PLA.
Sliced and printed with Cura.

description.text:
Behold: DupliGator! This is probably my best Thingiverse posting yet. I'm very excited to share with you, via non-commercial license, the DupliGator. It works just like the machine at the hardware store that copies keys, like a router duplicator, and also like a lathe duplicator except that there is no motorized machinery and it works in 3D.

The idea is that you glue a source object to one geared platform using glue stick or other temporary glue, then you adhere a destination object in a removable way to the other gear. Next if you are right handed, you hold the gears steady with your left hand and guide the tool with your right hand over the source object, theoretically carving the destination material into the desired shape (approximately).

Now do be forewarned that this is a work in progress and I do not have any wax, clay, or chocolate for testing. So if you spend half a day printing this thing (if all goes well) and it does not work, do not be disappointed. I have tested it with no destination object and it works great in theory and in application. The best method is not to make stabbing or chiseling motions but rather to drag the toolhead over the work.

So if it's untested, why am I so excited? Well, not everybody is a 3D printing enthusiast with a scanner and 3D software expertise. In fact, as you know, there are far more people who do not have the time or inclination to get into our hobby or work. So this DupliGator is for them! To make a one-off copy of some object in chocolate for a cake topper, it's the wOw factor that they need. Also creators who wish to make lost wax statues can use this thing. The applications go on and on with the imagination.

Please note that the gears, counterrotating as gears like to do, will cause a mirrored object to be made. It will take an improvement to the OpenSCAD file (which I plan to do in time) to add a third gear for making non-mirrored objects.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

18%

Notes:

note that there is a nozzle size parameter at the top of the file. The STL files print with a 0.4 mm nozzle.

Also please note that there are wide-ish hinges that require farily long-ish bridging capability of your printer. Be forewarned that if your printer can't bridge 25 mm then your print of the base may be locked up and either not print or break when you crack the joint.

Print two gear.stl files and one base.stl files, put the gears on the base in the obvious locations, and you're good to go!

Divine Inspriation

We can do all things through Christ who gives us strength, as it says in the bible. Also Jesus told us that he is the vine and we are the branches, so with Him we can do great things and without Him we can do nothing.

I personally credit the Lord with most of my ideas and I offer the following concept as evidence: The speed of an idea tells of its source. If I work on something and apply my God-given talents over time, I call it my own idea or work. However if I get one of those light bulb moments, an epiphany or sudden insight then i know it is of divine inspiration simply because the brain does not work that fast. The brain is electrochemical in nature and each neuron firing takes a certain amount of time and many many neurons have to fire in succession and repetition to crank out a thought.

I'd like to get an opinion on that from some researchers who study the brain, as it may not be correct but either way I will still maintain that sudden insights are from the Lord.

remixed_from.title: Thumbwheel M3 with scale 0.01 mm with grip (Nut on bottom)

description.text:
This is another version of the thumbwheel to replace the m3 wingnut on the Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Cocoon Create / Monoprice Maker Select.

It requires 4x m3 nuts to install. The nut recesses are quite tight, i recommend using long nose pliers to press them into place.

I also reccommend using this in conjunction with a locknut underneath the heated aluminium to stop the m3 bolt from spinning.

I prefer the larger wings, they are easier to turn finely than the more popular round style knurled thumbwheels.

Edit: Due to feedback/comments, I have added a smaller version which should clear the printer frame in certain cases where the original size was running into things, although I had no problems with the original size.

Edit: For any further changes, you can use this link to make a copy and edit using OnShape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/be1f228b579d4336988c6cb8/w/5a05657c1cc382bbebb4fab8/e/d1a8e55a81200a8af491cb3b

Edit: as requested, I have added 5.25mm and 5.75mm hex holes to allow for different types of m3 nuts and for various printers undersizing/oversizing holes.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15-0.25

Infill:

Doesn't Matter

Install m3 nuts

After printing, use a small hobby knife to cut away any excess plastic inside the m3 nut recess, and use long nose pliers to press the m3 nuts into their new home.

title: SW Equinox ED80 focus motor connector

description.text: This simple design will directly connect a focus stepper motor (specifically, a NEMA14 19:1 geared motor) to a SkyWatcher Equinox ED80 pro telescope to automate focusing. It also needs a flexible drive coupler as shown (you can print one if you like, there are designs on Thingiverse but I used an aluminium one because I had some in stock). Just loosen a single screw and remove the focus knob, attach the motor to the connector using 4 x 3mm machine screws, push the motor bracket onto the focuser housing (see pics) and secure in place with a single 4mm screw. The tapped hole is already there on the scope for this purpose.

title: BMW R100 Kofferhalter V2 - luggage holder

description.text:
The luggage holder on my BMW was broken. Looking for spare I had the idea to construct the holder as a clamp. The case must be held tight , but can also degrade rapidly .
Assembly:
First screw the locking ring on the clamp. Use a M3 screw.
The luggage holder is glued to the trunk and then additionally secured with rivets or screws . Subsequently, the cover plate is glued over it.
The case is then clicked on the tube holder . Close the lock ring and it´s safe ... finished...
To remove it just open the lock ring and pull the case from the carrier.

This is V2. At http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1564278 I told you to make ab better one: So here it is.

Feel free to adjust it for your Bike. And don´t forget to like it ;)

author: w-sellschopp

title: Socket & tip for custom partial finger replacement

description.text:
Updates to this design as of 11/6/14:
  • Increased the size of the cable & bungee channels
  • Improved the shape of the fingertip
  • Increased the thickness and durability of the structure to prevent the fingers from bending backwards
  • Added bars to tie the cable & bungee off too
    This is the first in a series of 3 things that, when combined, can be used as a device for some partial finger amputees missing more than half of their finger. It's customizable so that it can be adjusted to the size of the user's hand and fingers.
    Included in the "files" section is a PDF document with a measurement guide and instructions on assembly.
  • All measurements must be in millimeters.
    This thing contains the socket that fits over the finger stump and the artificial finger tip.
    A video showing someone trying out the device can be seen here: http://youtu.be/WlfS02OAKcU
    I see this as just a starting-point (and a rather rough one at that). I would love for other designers to take the source files, experiment, re-mix and improve upon this. :)
    This design is part of the ongoing work of the E-Nable group.
    For more information on where to connect with people who can help someone in need with sizing, printing and/or assembly a mechanical hand please join the e-NABLE Google+ Community entitled, e-NABLE:
    https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
    For more information and stories:
    http://enablingthefuture.org
    https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization

Included in the "files" section is a PDF document with a measurement guide and instructions on assembly.
  • All measurements must be in millimeters.

This Mk7 replacement features a spring-tensioned, quick-release 623 bearing idler, and won't interfere with dualstrusion. The back is also open to make it easy to clean the teeth of the drive gear.
This works with MBI's Mk7 and QU-BD's MBE extruders. It will fit the Mk8 as well, but the Replicators have plates above the extruders that will interfere with the spring arm. There are several derivatives that solve this problem, most at the expense of the rear clean-out opening.
The best shaft for the bearing seems to be an M3x10mm flat-head screw, inserted from the motor side of the idler piece. A piece of 3mm filament should also work in a pinch.

comments.text: I love this thing!  The stock MK7 extruder constantly gave me problems.  This one always works perfectly.  My only complaint is when it's time to change the filament it's hard to feed in the new piece.  This is the way I do it, but it's still a little tricky: First if there is already filament in the machine I cut it off close to the extruder inlet with a pair of diagonal cutters.  Then I run the stepper until all of the filament has been drawn past the motor.  Then I stop the stepper, push the lever and insert a small allen wrench (the same size as the filament) into the hole.  I feel around until I find the top of the filament and push.  I feel the resistance as I push it into the extruder and then the slight bump as it hits the entrance to the tube.  I continue to push until it has bottomed-out inside the tube (this is important).  Then I remove the allen wrench.  I take the new filament and try to remove the curl and make it as straight as possible.  I press the lever again and while holding it down (here comes the hard part) I try to find the entrance to the tube and push it in.  I release the lever and run the stepper and hopefully stuff comes out!
comments.author: charliearmorycom

comments.text: It's easier if you pull the old filament out rather than trying to push the last piece through. As for difficulty lining up the new piece, I'm working on a new version that will fix this: https://plus.google.com/105535247347788377245/posts/8FCXgHdxrJwhttps://plus.google.com/105535...

comments.text: I upgraded my MK7 motor with a higher-torque motor to be able to print PLA faster (which it now does), but I had to drill the hole in the feeder gear to 6mm and I didn't quite get it on center.  The Makerbot plunger system didn't have enough range of motion to pick up the slight difference, especially on thinner (1.6ish mm) filament so it would feed for a bit when the gear was slightly closer to the plunger, and slip when it was slightly away from the plunger.  I printed this replacement out, and even with it not feeding properly all the time, it was good enough to install and it worked lilke a champ.  I printed another copy, now that it was feeding continuously, and it came out great.  Thanks!

So I switched back to the original MK7 but removed the cooler plate so that the cooling air from the fan could cool down the place where the drive-gear and the filament meet each other. author: midiwei

title: Axle pin & anchor for Custom partial finger replacement

description.text:
Update as of 11/6/14:
  • Replaced the tie-off anchor with a wrist-mounted tensioner from the e-NABLE Raptor Hand.
    This is the third in a series of 3 things that, when combined, can be used as a device for some partial finger amputees missing more than half of their finger. It's customizable so that it can be adjusted to the size of the user's hand and fingers.
    Included in the "files" section is a PDF document with a measurement guide and instructions on assembly.
  • All measurements must be in millimeters.
    This thing contains the cable anchor worn on the back of the user's wrist as well as the snap-pin for the axle on the artificial finger. These files are static (non-customizable).
    A video showing someone trying out the device can be seen here: http://youtu.be/WlfS02OAKcU
    I see this as just a starting-point (and a rather rough one at that). I would love for other designers to take the source files, experiment, re-mix and improve upon this. :)
    This design is part of the ongoing work of the E-Nable group.
    For more information on where to connect with people who can help someone in need with sizing, printing and/or assembly a mechanical hand please join the e-NABLE Google+ Community entitled, e-NABLE:
    https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
    For more information and stories:
    http://enablingthefuture.org
    https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization

Included in the "files" section is a PDF document with a measurement guide and instructions on assembly.
  • All measurements must be in millimeters.

Then, recently I offered one in another favorite, Helvetica. So why not just create a whole mess of them!? Rather than flooding Thingiverse with Ampersands, I'm creating this one thing as a sort of collection of Ampersands. I'll periodically update this thing with new printable files. author: Verstraete

description.text:
After several years of a relationship as well as lots of research, reading, designing and several rounds of prototypes it is time for a big decision to be made. Here is the engagement ring I presented to my intended recently as well as a brief description of it and the design process. The design is based on a Tiffany Etoile Solitaire Ring and features a 0.31C internally flawless round brilliant Tolkowsky cut Fancy Intense Blue (Boron Doped) Cultured Diamond set in a flared semi-bezel crown of 950 Platinum-Iridium on a D-shaped "Court" Band of 950 Palladium-Ruthenium. It seems most goldsmiths & jewellers I talked to prefer not to work with Palladium, multiple-metals, custom designs, stones they have not purchased themselves, cultured diamonds or non-white diamonds. This design features all of these so getting a goldsmith who would work with me on this project was tough and it was barely finished in time. Getting the diamond was also a challenge, as it was held up in customs for several weeks leaving very little time for the goldsmith to actually make the ring. In spite of this the end product had excellent workmanship and looked fantastic! As a side note, the pictures don't do the stone justice, it is really sparkly and appears a deep blue in bright light. Changes from previous version:
1.0
  • Changed dimensions to those used in the final version
  • Changed Band to Rounded hemi-ellipse type
  • Removed second crown
  • Added a bowtie cutout to the ring band for the mount to sit into
  • Made the crown section taller and raised the diamond with it to better show it off and prevent the cutlet or point of the diamond from protruding from the hole at the bottom of the crown

• Find yourself in relationship with someone
  • Realise you connect with them on a deep level and want to be with them forever
  • Design prototype ring, repeat until satisfied
  • Acquire resources, materials & ring size of intended
  • Become highly skilled metal smith OR locate skilled artisan willing to take on a custom design
  • Use previously gathered resources and ring size to make object
  • Wait...
  • Present to intended
    • Note:
    Don't forget to insert needless paperwork, delays, indecision, uncertainty & frustration at almost every step of the way

title: Hex: it's not just for honey! HEX 2.0

description.text:
Hex: HEX 2.0
Thank you everyone for adding HEX to your workspace, and liking it. Due to your encouragement, I have created HEX 2.0! It's just like the first one, but 2 x better! Really, I just made it look a little cleaner, and easier to put together. I have uploaded the new files, print away!

Interesting fact: Bees are a very organized, institutionally intelligent group. An example of their brilliance, the Honeycomb! It is more than just part of a larger structure. The honeycombs produced by a worker bee are brilliant in their design. Uniform wall thickness, and very thin, approximately 0.05 mm, that's 1/20th of a millimeter. Combined, they become a stiff strong supportive structure, that is still flexible enough to survive stresses from wind and other elements.

Why I was motivated to design this

So I printed these hex boxes. I hate drawers to be the home for screws, they pull out or overflow, or get mixed, etc. So, I printed something flat, so I could see how many screws I had, and if they were mixing. I also wanted something I could move around a lot that wouldn't get knocked over, and that I could pull screws out of quickly. It has changed my life, my hair has almost started growing back, and I am less stressed. Enjoy my first upload Thingiverse, and thanks to all of you for such a cool 3D printing community!

Additional steps:

  1. Up Scaling
Project Name: A Bee's Storage Unit

Overview & Background: Objectives: Audiences:

Anyone who wants to bee more organized.

Subjects: Skills Learned (Standards):

Engineering Tip: Looking to Nature
When approaching an engineering problem, start by looking at nature for ideas. For example, the Honeycomb for structural dynamics, or the snail shell for a turbo charger in a car. Engineering requires creativity, and creativity requires knowledge. Nature is an infinite wealth of knowledge.

title: CMW Speed Addict 180/210-R GoPro Session Mount

description.text:
This is a TPU (NinjaFlex) mount for the GoPro Session specifically designed to fit the CMW Speed Addict 210-R. It should also fit the 180 as the plate should be the same as the 210.

This has been a great addition and protects the camera very well during crashes.

The angle is 25 degrees which I find to fit my flying style very well. CMW sells a 35 degree tilt but that gives a little too much angle for me so I designed this version.

The mount accepts a standard r/c velcro strap.

Please don't ask me if it will fit other branded frames as I have no idea what other frames it may or may not fit.

Printer:

MendelMax3

Rafts:

No

Yes

0.2

25%

Print Temp 225°C

I typically start out at 240 for the first layer then ramp the temps down to 225 by the 5th layer.
Designed in Solidworks.

author: glennbob

title: MakerBot Dioder Light Mounts and Replacement Connector

description.text:
45 degree mounts for Ikea Dioder strip lights and
replacement connector for a repurposed Ikea Dioder connector.

Lights
  • Use two light strips from an Ikea Dioder strip light set ( http://www.flickr.com/photos/txoof/6675018633 )
  • Print six 45 degree mounts - you will only need two per light, but they may crack as you add the screws
  • Mount one light on the left and right inside corners using hot glue.
  • Route the wire through the left and right front holes
  • Mount a Clas Ohlson LED Spot Light on the bottom of the Z Stage ( http://www.clasohlson.co.uk/Product/Product.aspx?id=162502340 ). The Clas Ohlson light connector is compatible with the Ikea connectors.
  • Route the wires through the back right corner into the base.
    • Power
  • Snip off the Ikea power connector leaving ~30cm of wire.
  • Wire the connector into a 12V rail (yellow +, Black ground). Note the polarity of the power connector wires by checking the Ikea wall-wart with a multi meter
    • Replacement Connector
    You should have a perfectly good 12V wall-wart with a great switch left over and probably a few spare light strips. Make a replacement connector using this thing.
  • Print out the box
  • Use proto board (20mmx31mm) to make a simple circuit with all three pin headers in parallel with the power supply. Note the polarity of the wall-wart and your headers.
  • The box will hold the proto board in a sandwich.
  • Plug it in and test it.

title: Rotor Riot Fatshark Fan shroud Guard Shield Protector

description.text:
This is a mash-up of three brilliant people's ideas. Original fan guard design was by Miles Incley posted to the Rotor Riot Facebook Group. Which was awesome, meaning that anyone who bought a pair of fatsharks before they added the feature now gets to have the awesome fan guard too. Daryl Tingley then decided to add the Rotor riot logo to it so that to give the pilot maximum swag, he took sp3cialk's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/sp3cialk) and added it on top of the guard. I simply took both designs and mashed them together so that everyone can access them :D
Miles also included a link to shapeways for his part just in case you don't have a 3D printer and want the regular fan shroud so you can check that out over at his post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1575565

EDIT 27/5/16:
Miles uploaded his Version 1.5 fan shroud (with rounded corners and other small tweaks) so I added it to the options available. I also removed the blank Shroud files as they are indeed Miles' design and you can go download them from his post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1575565
happy printing :D

25-100

title: Raspberry Pi 3 - Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this case to fit a Raspberry Pi 3. I left a lot of room for airflow, but also some protection. All ports should be accessible in this model.

It's held together with 4 M2x8 screws. The inner support posts have holes to accept the screws and are slightly undersized, so the first time the screws are turned in, it creates threads. I printed this in PLA plastic, so the threads are not super strong, but plenty to keep the top on.

There will be a video of the design/printing of this case over on my YouTube channel http://www.youtube.com/diodepress along with my other 3D printing projects.

UPDATE June 30, 2017:
I've added a new SNAP fit version of this case to the listing, as well as an option to mounting onto the LulzBot Mini printer. This eliminates the need for the M2 screws.

description.text:
UPDATED INFORMATION 29/08/2016
Ok I've added some pictures of printed version for tt motor... :( not only good news...

Drmn4ea warn in is description that this pump need a lot of torque... he's right... my plan was to use tt motor which are plastic gear motor... the problem was the size of the tube that I have selected... way too big (10 mm od 8mm id silicon tubing) ... I was on my way to build a bar tender robot for my wedding ... but with a month of delivery time for my fda silicone tubing... ordering the wrong size made me miss my time window... but don't worry this project is not dead... it remains me a lot of future party to justify the effort over this one ;)

I also see some user having difficulty with tube seal... the key factor of this is the tolerance value...

UPDATED on 6/10/2016

Compact: mount hole distance =0.75*OD

UPDATED on 5/30/2016

New Feature : 28BYJ-48 motor Mount!

Parametric 28BYJ-48 motor Mount could now be generated by setting Motormount_type=2.

Don't forget to set (you should add some tolerance to those number) :
CenterHole_dia = 5
CenterHole_Num_of_Flat = 2
CenterHole_Flat_dia = 3

I didn't test it at the moment but all dimension are based on the 28BYJ-48 motor spec so it should be correct. It support Both type of Pump mount.

The gap between the mount and the pump is set to 5mm...

Enjoy!

UPDATED on 5/25/2016

New Feature : TT motor Mount!

Parametric TT motor Mount could now be generated by setting Motormount_type=1.

I didn't test it at the moment but all dimension are based on the tt motor spec so it should be correct. It now support Both type of Pump mount.

Enjoy!

UPDATED on 5/20/2016

I've just add parametric center hole type, with default set to arduino yellow tt motor (circle with two flat...the one that i want to use for my project... for generating the original center simply set: CenterHole_Dia=0 CenterHole_Num_of_Flat=6 CenterHole_Flat_Dia=5.5

the STL remain with the original center screwdriver hex hole.

It now support motor shaft with 1 to 8 flat or round one (next step would add round shaft lock screw...)

Also I want to add an parametric motor mount for this pump...

Original Post

I was in the need of a mount bracket for the impressive Drmn4ea's Parametric Peristaltic Pump. So I've Add two model of mounting bracket to the scad file (Compact and Standard).

Standard: mount hole distance =1.25*OD

Those mount are optional, so you could disable them using variable.

I also add a quick fix to the Outer Diameter Calculation, So now the resulting OuterDiameter is not oversized.

Hope it would be useful :)

This thing could be customized using the Customizer App, but please note that a strange display glitch append when the tubing_squish_ratio is < 0.41 ... this glitch didn't appear in openscad...

Designed Using Freecad first and ported to OpenScad.

title: Battle Mech (Wargaming Mini)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a derivative of the Kanazuchi Battle Armor by Blaar in the sketchup warehouse. http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=437c8265b8dc1d4d8f012e721fb92cd5&prevstart=0 This is the second model in my all printed warmachine army. See the first one for more details. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15713 This model was exceptionally well made as is. It took very little editing to get printed well. Major compliments to the original author. Other then the hands, the entire model can reasonably be printed as a single piece. I did the slicing with SFACT other slicers were having problems. There is a "it's not a bug, it's a feature" style hollow spot in the middle of the torso. Update 1/13/12
I've finished the first set of custom bits for him. If you're familiar with the game Warmachine I'm playing him as a proxy for the ironclad chassis warjacks. The default load out for that is a warhammer and a fist. Those are uploaded now as the iron_part1 and 2 stls. They are a bit of a rush job so far but they will do for now. Update 1/20/12
At a friends suggestion I redid his fist. Some one yelled "He's going to get the clamps" in the Futurama voice. Update 1/23/12
I've added another set of bits. It's a sword and buckler set. You will need to print those, the torso with legs and the clamps hand to finish the model out. The sword handle is extra long to add cooling time to the blade. I recommend trimming it when the print is finished. Note: Warmachine and the related terms are property of privateer press. This model is not intended to actually look like or be the model they provide but is simply my proxy for it.

Just so it's clear the 'alpha' version is the one that's totally assembled.  I don't recommend printing it that way.  If you want it mostly assembled at least print the one without the hands attached.
Print and assemble. When I make some to paint I'll also pin all the joints as they aren't very secure as is.
The model in parts is ~60mm tall

This is a very powerful 10-watt flashlight that is perfect for your workshop or just as a powerful flashlight. It runs off of a 500mah 3s 11.1v lipo battery. This tiny light cranks out a whopping 1,000 lumens. The assembly video listed below includes links to all the parts and tools you will need to build it. A GoPro mount can be used to attach any GoPro handle, or you can use one of our own custom handles. A 26mm external diameter acrylic rod is used for our custom rod handle.

Assembly Video:
-https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qZ_pkNzasyQ

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I recommend that you use simplify 3D as a slicing program because their supports are super easy to get off. Make sure to put all parts that have a raft .3mm off the raft or the raft can be hard to get off. If I don't mention a specific setting, just use your current setting.

-Print the body file with supports and a raft in PLA.
-Print the rod handle with supports ant 100% infill.
-Print the back with no rafts or supports.
-Print the pistol grip with a raft and no supports.

Step 1: Remove all supports

When you are done printing, there will be some supports on the mainframe/body and your rod handle extension. Carefully remove these supports with a pair of long nose pliers. If there are any other bits of bumpy/sharp pieces of plastic left on the outside of your mainframe/body make sure to remove them with your pliers.

Step 2: Assembly

Now that you have your 3D printed parts, you can move on to the next step of assembly. We have created a step by step tutorial video on youTube for you all to watch. We hope you all enjoy this project as much as we did!

- Tutorial Video

title: XBox Trigger Adapter for The Controller Project contest

description.text: Breaks out the trigger and buttons from the front of the XBox 360 controller so that they can be used from the top. Design is in response to Caleb Kraft's call for a controller mod that could be used by someone with physical limitations. Check out his good work here: The Controller Project This might be a good mod for you if you can't bend your trigger fingers. Any suggestions for improvement are welcome. Assembly video at YouTube Another mod which brings the control of the trigger/button to one side is here

• Print a platter of parts.

  • Enlarge holes in all pieces except the stand (spacer base) with a 9/64ths drill bit.

  • Assemble as pictured with a 2 inch #6 pan head machine screw. Tighten just enough that there is slight resistance on the levers.

  • Slide onto your wireless XBox 360 controller and secure by pulling the hook-ish side into place.

description.text:
This hand is made to Loosely function the way a human hand does. By weaving rubber bands, or other elastic fasteners through the top of the hand, through the built in cavities, you can mimic the way a normal hand would recoil after being closed into a fist. You can then fishing line or string through the bottom of the hand and fingers to act as tendons, so that the hand will open and close at will. Relaxing the strings would thus let the hand open back up due to the rubber bands pulling on the opposite side of the hand. All in all, this hand would help teach the dynamics of a human hand in action.

 This hand would require rods of some kind to be inserted in the knuckles, as these parts don't "snap" together. Better yet, students could be tasked with designing clips and rods to fit in the knuckles off a 3D design engine, such as Inventor. You could even go as far as to design a wrist portion to attach to the end of a broom stick or something of that sort to extend the reach. This product would be a very useful teaching aid for a biology class or lesson...

My printer is in the same room as my exercise machine and I think the filament gets pretty sweaty.. So these hopefully will keep the in use filament dry. pockets in the back panel to hold silica desiccant beads to absorb any moisture that gets in. A work in progress I have already gone from halves to thirds as the long edge was shrinking by about 1.5mm.
The 200mm x 3mm acrylic tube was about ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ£17 for 250mm on ebay and they very nicely cut it as two 125mm for me at no extra cost.
This is a work in progress and I will post parts as I get them finalised. New 3 part back and nut are uploaded. The nut might only be useful if you have the same clone machine as me, it uses 30mm plastic tube for the filament holders. Adding parts for 220mm tube to fit the bigger 200mm reels. Might fit one of each size as two of the bigger ones practically touch leaving just a 6mm gap between tubes, that might make getting the cable run between them awkward. Got one side complete used a 32mm hole saw for the exit hole and had to make a longer version of my filament support. Also elongated the reel support hole to move the centres apart. Just need to find some suitable sponge or foam to plug the exit.

description.text:
This is my mounting design for a digital thermometer to read the temperature of my aquarium.

It can be used everywhere you want, it just holds the display, letting the wire and the sensor to fall down and reach the place where you need to read the temperature.

It is design to fit thermometers like this one:
https://www.amazon.es/gp/product/B00CKIF0PK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

They can be found very cheap (1 or 2 €) also in AliExpress, Gearbest, Banggood... they are pretty much standard.

The basic mount is composed of 2 STL models:

  • Box: to hold the display
  • Clamp: in case you need to mount it on an aquarium, terrarium... any kind of vertical wall (4mm thick or more)

If your display doesn't fit tightly, and is a bit lose, there is another STL:

  • Supplement: to fill the interior gaps so it stays firmly. Print them only if it's loose, any other case they are not needed.

I had to print both of the supplements because my thermometer arrived a bit damaged on the sides, but it stays very well with them.

At the back, it has enough space to save the extra wire it has, so you can control how many wire you want. It can be holded with the same cable it brings to keep all the wires together.

The clamp is removable, and can be changed for anything else, if it doesn't fit you needs, as long as the new mount fits the hole the box has at the bottom. It can be seen in the stl model, it's a square hole of 20 x 5 mm.

Hope you find it useful. Please comment if you have any doubt.

description.text:
Bran Castle was made by a team of students during the 3D Printing workshop @UTech Lab.

Bran Castle, commonly known as "Dracula's Castle", is a national monument and landmark in Romania. It is the seventeenth and last landmark designed during the series of 3D printing workshops @UTech Lab. After each workshop, one landmark is added to the Europe 3D Printed Map (thing:1002482) located in the ground floor of the lab.
Monuments already made include the Big Ben (thing:1041101), the Eiffel Tower (thing:1060135), the Parthenon (thing:1067082), the Belem Tower (thing:1099449), the Sagrada Familia (thing:1101544), the Colosseum (thing:1103617), the Pisa Tower (thing:1129396), the Brandenburg Gate (thing:1160276), Saint Basil's Cathedral (thing:1235054), White Tower of Thessaloniki (thing:1297119), Hagia Sophia (thing:1313680), Stortorget (thing:1333136), Grundtvig's Church (thing:1363388), Hallgrímskirkja (thing:1389710), Hermitage museum (thing:1487299) and the Dutch Windmill (thing:1501801).

For more information, please visit our website:
http://eugenweb3.eugenfound.edu.gr/utech

remixed_from.title: Wanhao I3 Filament Guide for Top Spool Holder

title: Filament Guide Locking Part for Wanhao i3

description.text:
A locking insert for the "Filament Guide for Top Spool Holder" by Grezmel (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:979847).

I loved Grezmel's design over the other filament guides, but the filament did have a habit of finding its way out of the slot on the front, especially when the head was raised in the Z.

This is just a little part I designed to snug-fit inside the filament loop on the guide to completely secure the filament inside. I've created it so that there is a smooth entry and exit from the insert (using bevels), and once installed it is a friction fit but can still be turned or removed when needed.

There are 2 STL files, basically the same part but flipped upside down - I printed from the upside down file (does not require support, but I was worried about the slight overhang at the base of this file so provided both). I printed both ways round on my first attempt (shown in photo 2), but please note you only need to print the part once.

Printer:

Wanhao i3 Duplicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I have included files for printing either way up, I used both on the same plate to see which would be best (the right way up one I printed with support), and they both printed out completely fine, so I'd first try printing from the file named 'Upside Down' first which doesn't need support.

I wanted a strong part so printed virtually 100% infill, but I'm sure it would be fine with less.
I designed this in Cinema 4D using the model for the filament guide as a, well, guide, and then exported as an STL file to bring in to Simplify3D for slicing.

comments.text: Very nice. It prints quickly and fits perfectly! I had the same problem with the original filament guide and this fixes the problem without having to print an entire new guide.
comments.author: blingster

print_settings.Notes:: I did the Tri, or three legged adapter to reduce print time and material. In the end, I really like the simplicity of it, that it is small and that it works smoothly.

description.text:
... I give you the Tri-Adapter Axle.

I started by measuring the inside diameter of the spools that I had. I came up with 4 common sizes, all included in my design. I haven't found a spool (yet) that doesn't work.

I used a 3D printed angle bracket for PVC that I made and some PVC fittings to mount it above my printer. With 3/8" ID bearings that pop into the Tri-Adapter body, the whole thing easily screws into a 3/8" coupling nut I mounted in an adapter I also printed that presses into the PVC fittings, all freely spinning on a common 3/8" bolt as an axle. I ended up getting two different length bolts for different width spools, but one long bolt could work for all spools.

I hope it serves you well - ENJOY!

UPDATED 11/14/2017
Added STEP (.stp) file for anyone who would like to modify this design. STEP files open in a variety of different CAD packages including AutoDesk's FREE Fusion 360.

Also, I found some spools the original adapter didn't work with, so I added one more step to included that size spool. But, I also made a "Universal" and self centering adapter.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3 mm, you choose.

Infill:

Yes, I use 30-50%

Notes:

Use your favorite settings and slicer for this part, it is pretty forgiving and should function properly even if it prints rough or ugly. I usually try to avoid supports to keep my stress levels at a minimum, but the bearing housing benefits from support.

I did the Tri, or three legged adapter to reduce print time and material. In the end, I really like the simplicity of it, that it is small and that it works smoothly.
Remove support material... pop in some bearings... DONE.

I tried other "spool holders", but they all hang-up or bind sooner or later. Other "rollers" require filament guides and occupy work surface space. I wanted a spool holder that was out of the way, didn't clutter up my work space and provided smooth distribution of filament preferably with bearings that I could change out when needed for a variety of spool sizes.

When I used other "holders", often I would have to tighten my filament feeder bearing so tight it would smash and oblong the filament so it wouldn't fit through the extruder and would jam up. This ruins a lot of filament quickly. Other "rollers" need guides to get the filament up and over everything to get the filament from the spool to the extruder because they sit on the work surface. Each of these "guides" can also jam up the filament or require bearings themself. It seemed that it could all be done easier...

comments.text:
I use 8 mm. all thread rods 12" long and skate bearings 608ZZ 8x22x7. You should check out my stuff
@ http://www.thingiverse.com/kb3lnn/designs
comments.author: kb3lnn

comments.text: Bro you have got a TON of stuff! I dig it! 3/8" is definitely overkill for this purpose, but not much larger than 8mm, closer to 5/16". I am 6'4", 200 lbs, I have big hands so the 3/8" is comfortable for me. 3/16" to 1/4" would have been fine, but my mitts would fumble around with them. I do a lot of things with 2-3 mm Allen head bolts and my fingers hate it. The 8mm skate bearings are a good idea though, very common and easy to find, I use them from time to time but should maybe make them my staple just due to availability. Also at my goto bearing store: https://www.thebigbearingstore.com/ , the 8mm are $0.87 each compared to the 3/8" at $1.58 each, so even more reason to switch.
comments.author: kb3lnn

description.text:
this is a upgraded electronics box for the m2. the lid can be screwed down so it wont pop up and come undone like the factory one. this also contains a lock on the back side which holds in the power connectors so they do not come loose or fall out. 90% of the factory hardware is used on this. the lid can be screwed down with a #8 sheet metal screw on each corner or on the inside there is a slot sized for an m3 hex nut so you can use machine screws. this box has slightly more room inside as well.  all pieces print really well in abs. the main box you may need to print with a raft or tabs added to corners.  
support: you should only need support under the fan on the lid, the connector lock and on the main box only in the square openings. the oval vent holes print really well without any.  
update: i added a button for the emergency reset. i also added an optional spacer for the fan. i replaced my fan with a higher performance ball bearing fan. the stock fan kept going bad on me. the fan was silent outside the box but makes a noisy whine when mounted up into the lid. if you have this issue print the spacer and put it between the fan and lid. it will quiet the fan a little. stock makergear fan doesnt seem to have this problem.

comments.text: since its not really warm down under the printer i think pla would be fine in this case. i did print mine in abs. if i was to do it again it would be in petg.

description.text:
This is a 1/32 scale "12 ton coal wagon" for G scale (45mm) garden railways.
It is a remix of the open freight car 1:32 scale gauge 1 by UTJTrain, but because I work in 123D, I had to re-draw some of the parts.
The body prints well if you use PLA, but attempts to print in ABS so far have resulted in bad warping.
Before assembling, make sure that all clearance holes are the correct size, and drill out if necessary to get smooth movement.
The wheels can be either Spoked or Solid, and are set on 3mm stainless axles, 68mm long. You can fit longer 76 axles and fit directly to the side hubs, but then the "brakes" on the swinging arms will bind unless the swinging axles are fixed. The wheels are also the same size as those on LGB / PICO /Nuquida carriages so you can use their wheels if you prefer.
I have a separate thingyverse entry for the wheel design, which includes an assembly / alignment tool, but have included the wheels here.
The swinging axle takes standard LGB couplings, but I have also designed some magnetic sprung versions that you can print. Use three 2mm long by 2mm dia magnets in the loop, and one 2mm ling by 3mm diameter magnet in the hook. Adjust their distance apart so that the "tension" is not too strong and check that the hook can displace downwards easily when coupling. Some filing of the slotted hole helps. The couplings use 13mm long #4 pan head screws, (as do the swinging axle bosses.).

The buffer bar is screwed to the body and side axles with 10mm long 1.7mm pan head screws.

The side hubs were supposed to be symmetric, but the end holes to fit the buffer beams are not quite the same at each end, so it is better to print all four rather than try to duplicate the ones that look the same. When fitting, look closely at the buffer beam and you should see which part fits where. You can also add some more 1.7mm screws to hold these hubs in place, but I found the tabs were sufficiently tight that extra screws were unnecessary.
The photo shows two PLA printed wagons, with an early, and much less successful, ABS version in the background

Printer:

shapeoko

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

use supports to make sure that the overhanging swinging axle coupling part is supported, Also the side hubs have a small cut away and print better with supports.
PLA seems to be essential for the body, or else you will get warping.
I used 123D to design this. Some parts translated to solids easily, but I found it easier to redraw things like the swinging axles.
